questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in the right knee for the past few months. On examination, there is tenderness in the affected part with a reduced range of motion. A radiographic study revealed a solitary lytic lesion at the distal end of the femur and the microscopic appearance of the lesion is shown below. Which of the following is not an x-ray finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and microscopic appearance are suggestive of osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor and they are purely radiolucent.

Microscopically they are composed of mononuclear cells with macrophages. They are more common between the age of 20-40 and typically affect the metaphyses of long bones with a preponderance for the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius and proximal humerus.

Important X-ray features of a GCT:

  • A solitary, possibly lobulated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Eccentric location, most often subchondral
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex
  • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance
  • No calcification within the tumor
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

 

 

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like distal ulna, clavicle, proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

questions.text: A middle-aged man was rushed to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. There was a severe injury in his left lower limb which got stuck between the vehicle and the road. The patient was treated conservatively but later developed oliguria, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia. Which of the following is not used in the management of his present condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of a lower limb stuck in between the vehicle and the road with the patient developing oliguria, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia is suggestive of crush syndrome. The alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate is done to prevent the precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules.

Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or rubble) and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites are released resulting in reperfusion injury. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants that escape into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. It is usually associated with compartment syndrome.

Management of crush syndrome involves aggressive volume loading of patients, management of the open wound, and excision of necrosed muscle to avoid sepsis. Encouraging high urine flow, along with alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate to prevent precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules. Renal hemofiltration is recommended if there is oliguria or renal failure. If compartment syndrome is confirmed (by measuring intra-compartmental pressure), then fasciotomy is performed. Fasciotomy should be avoided if entrapment is >12 hours as it can cause a massive release of myoglobin and spread the infection to dead tissues.

The image below shows compartment syndrome in the right upper limb managed by fasciotomy. 

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A male patient presents with gait abnormality. He had sustained a lower limb fracture 3 months back. After a detailed evaluation, he was prescribed the splint as shown in the image given below to correct the gait deformity. Which of the following fractures is responsible for the gait deformity for which he is being treated?

choices.text: Fracture of the lower third of tibia

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing an ankle-foot orthosis brace used for the treatment is suggestive of foot drop. It occurs due to common peroneal nerve injury, which is commonly caused by a fracture of the neck of the fibula.

The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and evertors of the foot. Injury to the common peroneal nerve results in foot drop. So the patient attempts to lift the leg high enough during walking so that the foot does not drag on the floor. This is known as a high-stepping gait.

Causes of common peroneal nerve injury:

  • Fracture of the fibular neck
  • Pressure from a splint or a plaster cast over the neck of the fibula

It is treated using an ankle-foot orthosis brace - a type of orthotic used to support the foot and ankle in foot drop.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of deformity as shown in the image given below. She gives a history of pain and stiffness in her hands and wrists for the past few years. The symptoms are worse in the morning and improve with physical activity. Which of the following is the most common hematological abnormality seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image given is of Boutonnière deformity seen in Rheumatoid arthritis and the most common hematologic abnormality seen in rheumatoid arthritis is normochromic normocytic anemia.

Rheumatoid arthritis is considered a chronic inflammatory disease with unknown etiology characterized by symmetric polyarthritis.

Clinical features of rheumatoid arthritis

Joints: Patients will have early morning stiffness of joints of the hand. This stiffness persists for around 1 hour and improves with physical activity. The most commonly involved joints are wrists, metacarpophalangeal (MCP), and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Chronic progressive destruction of the joint will lead to deformities.

  • Ulnar deviation: results from subluxation of the MCP joints, with subluxation, or partial dislocation, of the proximal phalanx to the volar side of the hand.
  • Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. 
  • Boutonnière deformity: flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint
  • Z-line deformity: subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint

Skin: Firm and non-tender nodules that are adherent to the periosteum, tendons, or bursae.

Sjogren syndrome

Pulmonary: Pleuritis is the most common pulmonary manifestation. It can also cause interstitial lung diseases.

Cardiac: It can cause pericarditis, cardiomyopathy, mitral regurgitation, etc.

Rheumatoid vasculitis presents as petechiae, purpura, digital infarcts, gangrene, livedo reticularis

Normochromic normocytic anemia

This disease is commonly associated with coronary artery disease, carotid atherosclerosis, osteoporosis, and hypoandrogenism.

 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of on-and-off back pain and stiffness in the morning that improves with exercise. Lately, she has been having persistent back pain and restricted chest movements. A CT scan was performed and is shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Earliest X-ray finding is bamboo spine appearance
There is a strong association with HLA B27
Young males are more commonly affected

questions.solution:
The clinical description and CT image showing bony ankylosis of the spine continuously involving the thoracolumbar vertebral bodies is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis. Continuous ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament is present. The earliest/cardinal sign is erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic progressive inflammatory condition of the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker. It commonly involves young male adults.

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months  

Examination findings:

  • Loss of lumbar lordosis
  • Increased thoracic kyphosis
  • Diminished spinal movements
  • Decreased chest expansion ( <7 cm)
  • Positive tests for sacroiliac joint involvement

Important X-ray features:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
    • Later- peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)
    • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels

questions.text: An elderly male presented with severe pain in his right hip following trauma 4 weeks back. An x-ray of the right hip showed a displaced fracture neck of the femur and a crescent sign. Which of the following is the best method of management of this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a history of pain in the hip following trauma with an X-ray showing a crescent sign is suggestive of osteonecrosis of the femoral head. Hemiarthroplasty is the best method of management of this condition.

Arthroplasty is surgery for reconstructing a joint to restore its function or relieve pain.

Types of arthroplasty

  • Excision arthroplasty: In this type of arthroplasty, one or both of the articular ends are excised. The fibrous tissue that fills the gap and provides movement at the joint. This is commonly performed in the hip or elbow.
  • Hemiarthroplasty: In this type of arthroplasty, only one of the articulating parts of the joint is replaced by a prosthesis (metal, silicon, or rubber). It is commonly performed for fractures of the neck of the femur in the elderly.
  • Total replacement arthroplasty: In this type of arthroplasty, both the articulating surfaces are excised and replaced by prosthesis. It is commonly performed for hip osteoarthritis.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with a history of fall on a flexed wrist with dorsiflexion and pronation of the forearm. On examination, there is tenderness and painful dorsiflexion of the wrist. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following statements are false about this condition?

choices.text: Unstable fractures are fixed with percutaneous pins or small screws
Conservative management is done with short arm cast
They are best seen on lateral view

questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with the X-ray showing the dorsal segment of distal radius fracture extending into the intra-articular region is suggestive of dorsal Barton's fracture. Barton's fractures are invariably intra-articular fractures. 

Barton’s fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. The dorsal or volar rim of the distal radius can be involved and they are named accordingly.

Dorsal Barton:

It involves fracture-dislocation of the dorsal rim of the distal radius. It is caused due to falling on the flexed wrist with dorsiflexion and pronation of the distal forearm. These fractures are best seen on the lateral view and the radiograph shows proximal and posterior displacement of the dorsal lip of the distal radial articular surface.

Treatment: Conservative management is by short arm cast with the wrist in the neutral position. Surgical management is by open reduction and internal fixation with percutaneous pins or small plates and screws.

Volar Barton/Palmar rim dislocation:

It involves fracture-dislocation of the anterior/palmar rim of the distal radius. It is caused by palmar tensile stress and dorsal shear stress and may be associated with radial styloid fractures. The radiograph shows dorsal displacement of the palmar rim of the distal radial articular surface.

Treatment: Conservative management - long-arm cast. Even though reduction is simple, retention is usually difficult. Surgical fixation with K- wires, external fixators, and buttress plates are considered if the reduction is not properly retained. Ellis-T-shaped buttress plate fixation is mostly preferred.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 12-year-old male child from a remote area is being examined for a defect in his legs. The parents of the child give a history his legs were plastered for a few months after birth. However, there was a lapse in further follow-up. On examination, the child is suffering from uncorrected Congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV). Which of the following is the best treatment option for the child?
questions.solution:
As the child is having Congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV) and his age is 12, Triple arthrodesis is the best treatment option for this child.

Triple arthrodesis consists of a fusion of the three joints of the foot-Talo-navicular joint, Talo-calcaneal joint, and Calcaneo-cuboid joint. It is done after 10-12 years of age when there is complete skeletal maturation. Of the three talonavicular joint fusion is the most difficult to achieve.

CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot. It is predominately seen in male children. The components of deformity are as follows:

  • Cavus: This deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint.
  • Adduction: This deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint.
  • Inversion: This deformity occurs at the subtalar joint. The calcaneum is inverted and along with it, the whole foot is inverted. This leads to a medially facing sole. 
  • Equinus: This deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

There is no previous history of any pain or discomfort in his leg. Which of the following statements about this condition is/are true?

2) It is the most common lesion of the bone
3) It is predominantly an epiphyseal tumor

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and radiological findings with well-defined lobulated lesion located eccentrically and sclerotic scalloped borders is suggestive of non-ossifying fibroma.

Common age of presentation of non-ossifying fibroma is 2-20 years. questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in his right shoulder. He gives a history of anterior dislocation of his right shoulder while playing football 4 years back, following which he had recurrent similar episodes. An X-ray of the patient is given below. The marked lesion in the image represents ______.
questions.solution:
The marked lesion in the image following recurrent anterior shoulder dislocations is suggestive of Hill-Sachs lesion. 

Hill-Sachs lesion is a compression fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head. It is caused by the pressure of the anterior glenoid rim on the humeral head seen in recurrent dislocations. 

Anterior dislocation is the commonest shoulder dislocation and can be caused due to trauma from behind the shoulder pushing the head out anteriorly. It is also caused due to falling on an outstretched hand in an abducted and externally rotated shoulder. It can be diagnosed on clinical examination with flattening of the shoulder contour and ability to place a rule (Hamilton ruler test) and the inability to touch his/her opposite shoulder (Duga's test). X-ray confirms the diagnosis and may show associated Hill Sachs or bony bankart lesion. The most common complication is recurrent shoulder dislocation.

Other options:

Bankart lesion is a tear in the anteroinferior part of the glenoid labrum caused by the head of the humerus during anterior dislocation. 

Option B: Janeway lesions-These are faint, red, painless macules on palms and soles seen in infective endocarditis.

Option D: It is the other name for inferior dislocation of the shoulder

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side. 

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

Brown color is due to cholesterol deposition

questions.solution:
Brown tumors are also known as Osteitis fibrosa cystica and Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone. It is seen in patients with hyperparathyroidism.

In the areas of bone resorption, the bone tissue is replaced with proliferating fibrous tissue, hemorrhage, and necrosed tissue. The hemorrhage leads to the accumulation of hemoglobin which is converted to hemosiderin. This hemosiderin gives it a brown color. The term tumor is a misnomer.

Other radiological features of hyperparathyroidism include:

  • Salt and pepper skull - It is seen due to the resorption of trabecular bone.
  • Subperiosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges
  • Osteitis fibrosa cystica - also called brown tumors and Von Recklinghausen's disease. In the areas of bone resorption, the bone tissue is replaced with proliferating fibrous tissue, hemorrhage, and necrosed tissue. The hemorrhage leads to the accumulation of hemoglobin which is converted to hemosiderin. This hemosiderin gives it a brown color. The term tumor is a misnomer.
  • Loss of lamina dura of teeth
  • Generalized osteopenia

questions.text: Following is a lumbosacral spine CT image of a patient who fell from a height while he was working. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of the fracture shown in the image?

choices.text: Bed rest is indicated only until acute symptoms settle
Stable fractures are managed with thoracolumbar brace for 12 weeks
Neurological injury is an indication for operative intervention
Fractures with  more than 25% canal compromise are treated operatively

questions.solution:
The lateral view CT image shows that the L4 vertebra has exploded. The posterior border of L4 has lost its concavity and has become convex. There is a posterior displacement of the bone into the spinal canal. This is diagnostic of burst fracture of the L4 vertebra and fractures with more than 50% canal compromise is considered as unstable and requires operative fixation.

Burst fracture results from severe axial compression that explodes the vertebral body. There is a failure of the anterior vertebral column and the posterior vertebral body is shattered. Fragments of bone and disc may be displaced backwards into the spinal canal (retropulsion). 

Radiological findings: 

  • AP view X-rays: Spreading of the vertebral body with an increase of the interpedicular distance may be seen.
  • Lateral view X-rays: Posterior displacement of bone into the spinal canal (retropulsion) can be seen at the posterosuperior border of the vertebral body. The normal concavity of the posterior vertebral body becomes convex in retropulsion. 

Management of burst fractures

  • Stable burst fracture: In minimal anterior wedging and when the fracture is stable (posterior ligament complex intact), with no neurological deficits, conservative treatment is followed. Bed rest until acute symptoms settle, followed by a thoracolumbar brace (TLSO) or body cast for about 12 weeks.
  • Unstable burst fracture: Operative treatment is done in cases of neurological injury, disruption of the posterior ligamentous complex (PLC), and if there is more than 50% canal compromise on CT. Posterior pedicle screw fixation is the standard treatment for PLC disruption.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty with a history of fall from a building on his feet. He complains of severe pain in his right foot and inability to walk following the injury. On examination, the patient was hemodynamically stable and all his peripheral pulses were present. questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of pain and swelling around the wrist following a fall on his outstretched arm. On examination, there was swelling around the wrist and tenderness in the anatomical snuff box. The patient was diagnosed with a displaced fracture and the following correction was done as shown in the image. Which of the following statements about this condition is/are true?

1) Non-union is a common complication of this fracture
2) Anteroposterior view is preferred over oblique view in recent fractures
3) It is the most common carpal bone fracture
4) Herbert's screw is used for internal fixation
5) Relative sclerosis of the proximal pole is pathognomonic of avascular necrosis
questions.solution:
The image of the Herbert screw and the clinical features are suggestive of a scaphoid fracture and the oblique view is preferred over the anteroposterior(AP) view in recent fractures.

Scaphoid fractures account for almost 75 percent of all carpal fractures although they are rare in the elderly and in children.

Mechanism of injury- The combination of forced carpal movement and compression, as in a fall on the dorsiflexed hand.

Diagnostic sign- precisely localized tenderness in the anatomical snuff box. 

X-ray-

  • Anteroposterior, lateral, and oblique views are all essential
  • Recent fractures are less likely to be visible on AP view x-ray, hence the oblique view is preferred. 
  • Usually, the fracture line is transverse, and through the narrowest part of the bone (waist), but it may be more proximally situated (proximal pole fracture).
    Old, un-united fractures have hard borders, making it seem as if there is an extra carpal bone.
  • Relative sclerosis of the proximal fragment is pathognomonic of avascular necrosis.

Treatment:

Undisplaced fractures are managed by immobilization in a neutral forearm cast for 6-8weeks. A scaphoid cast that incorporates the thumb in a glass holding position can also be used. Displaced fractures are managed by open reduction and internal fixation using Herbert's screw.

The common complications of scaphoid fracture include:

  • Non-union and delayed union
  • Avascular necrosis
  • Wrist osteoarthritis

Note:

Herbert Screw: It is cannulated and threaded at both ends. It is designed for use in fractures of small articular bones such as the carpals and the scaphoid.

questions.text: A boy got his hand stuck in the washing machine while it was functioning. He suffered a twisting injury resulting in a fracture of his right forearm. Which of the following fractures is most likely seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
As the patient suffered from a twisting injury, the most likely pattern seen in this condition would be a spiral fracture.

Fractures can be complete or incomplete. 

Complete fractures: Most fractures occur due to a combination of forces, but the dominant mechanism of force is revealed by the type of fracture:

  • Tension causes transverse fracture or avulsion of a small fragment of bone at the points of ligament or tendon insertion
  • The compression causes an oblique fracture
  • Bending causes fracture with triangular ‘butterfly’ fragment
  • Twisting (torsion) causes a spiral fracture


If the fracture fragments are jammed together and the fracture line is not visible, it is known as an impacted fracture.

If the fracture has more than two fragments, it is known as a comminuted fracture.

Incomplete fractures

  • Greenstick fractures: Bending forces can result in incomplete or “greenstick” fractures in the pediatric population. The bone doesn't break completely. The outer cortex breaks and the inner cortex bends causing the bone to buckle like snapping of a green twig.
  • Compression fractures: Cancellous bone crumple due to force. This is typically seen in vertebral bodies, calcaneum and the tibial plateau.

questions.text: An infant is being evaluated by the pediatrician due to the presence of short neck, facial asymmetry, and torticollis. There are no other significant clinical findings. An MRI was done and the image is given below. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Neurological features usually appear in the first year of life
It occurs due to birth trauma
Chamberlain’s line is used in the diagnosis

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the MRI are suggestive of basilar impression (basilar invagination) and Chamberlain’s line is used in the diagnosis of this condition. The image shows basilar invagination with indentation of the medulla oblongata by the odontoid process.

Basilar impression is a deformity in which there is an indention of the skull floor by the upper cervical spine. 

Basilar impression can be primary (congenital) or secondary (acquired).

  • Primary: Congenital defect in bone development at the craniocervical junction. The tip of the odontoid bone is more cranial than normal.
  • Secondary: Acquired deformity due to systemic diseases that affect bony structures at the base of the skull.

Symptoms: Neurologic symptoms due to pressure on the brainstem such as weakness and paresthesia in the limbs. These symptoms usually appear during the second and third decades of life. There can be symptoms related to compression of cranial nerves (trigeminal, vagus, glossopharyngeal, hypoglossal) and the vertebral artery.

Diagnosis: Craniometric parameters used for diagnosis include McRae’s line, Chamberlain’s line, McGregor’s line, and Fischgold and Metzger (Digastric) Line.

  • McRae’s line - It extends from the anterior tip to the posterior tip of the foramen magnum. The patient can be symptomatic if the tip of the odontoid is below this line.
  • Chamberlain’s line - This line extends from the posterior edge of the hard palate to the posterior border of the foramen magnum. The patient can be symptomatic if the tip of the odontoid is above this line.
  • McGregor’s line - This extends from the upper surface of the posterior edge of the hard palate to the most caudal point of the occipital curve. If the odontoid tip greater than 4.5mm is found above this line, it is considered abnormal.
  • Fischgold and Metzger (Digastric) Line - This line extends between the two digastric grooves. It normally passes 10.7 mm above the odontoid tip and 11.6 mm above the atlantooccipital joint. It is used to confirm the diagnosis.

 

In the image given above basion and opisthion are the anterior and posterior margins of foramen magnum respectively.

Treatment: Surgical decompression and stabilization with a posterior occipito-cervical arthrodesis. Odontoidectomy if compression is due to aberrant odontoid.

questions.text: A 24-year-old professional swimmer presents to the OPD with complaints of pain over his right shoulder. He gives a history that the pain is usually present after swimming practice sessions. On examination, the pain is aggravated when the arm is abducted between 60-120 degrees and the Hawkins-Kennedy test is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of painful arc syndrome.

Painful arc syndrome also known as impingement syndrome is a clinical syndrome in which there is pain in the shoulder and upper arm during the mid-range (between 60-120 degrees) of shoulder abduction. This arises because of the repetitive rubbing of the supraspinatus tendon under the coracoacromial arch.

Causes include:

  • Minor tears of the supraspinatus tendon
  • Chronic supraspinatus tendinitis
  • Calcification of supraspinatus tendon
  • Fracture of greater tuberosity 
  • Subacromial bursitis.

Important tests for impingement:

  • Painful arc test: When the patient is asked to actively abduct the arm, pain is aggravated during 60-120 degrees of abduction.
  • Neer's impingement sign- The examiner raises the affected arm to the full extent in passive flexion, abduction and internal rotation, with the scapula being stabilized with the other hand. The test is positive when pain located to the subacromial space or anterior edge of the acromion is elicited during the test.
  • Neer’s test for impingement: Disappearance or significant reduction in pain when the previous maneuver is repeated after injecting 10 mL of 1% lignocaine into the subacromial space. It helps in the confirmation of the diagnosis.
  • Hawkin-Kennedy's test- The patient's arm is elevated to 90 degrees in the scapular plane with the elbow flexed to 90 degrees. The examiner internally rotates the arm to full extent after stabilizing the upper arm with the other hand. The test is said to be positive when there is pain in the anterolateral aspect of the shoulder.
  • Jobe's test- The patient's arm is elevated in the scapular plane, and the elbow is extended with the thumb pointing to the floor. The patient is then asked to hold this position, while the examiner applies downward pressure. Pain indicates irritation of the supraspinatus tendon.

Other options:

Option B: Frozen shoulder/Periarthritis shoulder-Frozen shoulder is defined as the disorder characterised by progressive pain and stiffness in the shoulder joint which spontaneously resolves after around 18 months. The patient is usually in the age group of 40-60 years, presenting with pain in the shoulder which is initially worst at night but , later pain is present throughout the day and with all the movements.

 Option C: Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Option D: Meralgia paraesthetica- It occurs due to entrapment of lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh in the fascia just medial to anterior superior iliac spine leading to numbness, tingling and burning sensation in the area supplies by the nerve.

questions.text: A young man was brought to the casualty ward following a road traffic accident. He gives a history of having sustained a dashboard injury. On examination, his right lower limb is flexed, adducted, and slightly internally rotated. Which of the following is not a radiological finding seen in this condition?

choices.text: Femoral head appears smaller than normal
Femoral head is displaced above and behind the acetabulum
Prominent lesser trochanter on anteroposterior view

questions.solution:
The given history of dashboard injury and the examination finding of the right lower limb being in a flexed, adducted, and slightly internally rotated posture suggests posterior hip dislocation. Prominent lesser trochanter on anteroposterior view is not a radiological sign seen in this condition. 

Posterior dislocation of the hip occurs when the knee sustains a force injury. It occurs commonly after dashboard injuries.

Patients present with pain, swelling, history of severe trauma, and deformity. The deformity usually seen is flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. It is also associated with the shortening of the leg.

Radiological findings in posterior hip dislocation:

  • Femoral head is displaced above and behind the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualized
  • Femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen
  • Shenton's line will be broken 

Complications associated with posterior hip dislocation:

  • Injury to the sciatic nerve
  • Avascular necrosis of the femoral head
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Myositis ossificans

Treatment includes the reduction of dislocation as soon as possible. If not done within 6 hours, it could lead to osteonecrosis and osteoarthritis. Closed reduction of the dislocation should not be attempted if there is an associated femoral neck fracture.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old male child presents with complaints of high-grade fever, pain in the right knee joint for more than a week, and a recent episode of sore throat. Examination reveals knee joint tenderness. Laboratory evaluation showed elevated WBC count, ESR, and CRP. X-ray showed a faint extracortical outline in the proximal tibia. Which of the following is false regarding the complications associated with this condition?

WBC - White blood cell

ESR - Erythrocyte sedimentation rate

CRP - C-reactive protein

choices.text: Suppurative arthritis can occur if the metaphysis is intra-articular
Pathological fractures are not commonly seen in this condition
Epiphyseal damage is commonly seen in elderly individuals
Psuedoarthrosis can occur at the hip joint in  infants

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hematogenous osteomyelitis and epiphyseal damage is seen in neonates and infants.

Acute osteomyelitis

Causative organisms:

  • Staphylococcus is the most common organism causing osteomyelitis.
  • Pseudomonas is the most common cause in IV drug abusers
  • Salmonella is the most common cause in patients of sickle cell anemia
  • H.influenzae was a common causative organism in children, less common now because of vaccination
  • Streptococcus
  • E.coli

Route of infection: Acute osteomyelitis can be hematogenous or from exogenous routes such as open fractures, iatrogenic intervention, or spread from local infection.

Cardinal features of acute osteomyelitis in children include:

  • Fever
  • Pain
  • Refusal to bear weight
  • Elevated WBC count
  • Elevated CRP
  • Elevated ESR

X-ray findings:

  • During the first week, the X-ray appear to be normal and by the second week, a faint extracortical line may be visible due to periosteal new bone formation. This is a classic sign of early pyogenic osteomyelitis.
  • A combination of regional osteoporosis with a localized segment of apparently increased density is an important late finding in this condition.

Management of acute osteomyelitis:

Collection of blood samples for culture and sensitivity test, followed by immediate empirical antibiotic therapy to prevent septicemia and other complications. 

Surgical drainage is indicated only in the following two circumstances

  • Presence of an abscess requiring drainage
  • Whenever the patient does not respond to antibiotics

Supportive therapy includes analgesics, IV fluids, and splinting of the limb.

The complications of inadequately treated acute osteomyelitis include: 

  • Septicemia- Nowadays this is a rare complication due to prompt antibiotic therapy.
  • Epiphyseal damage and altered bone growth- This is seen in neonates and infants as their epiphyses are entirely cartilaginous. So the metaphysical vessels can penetrate into the physis and carry the infection to the epiphysis. In some cases involving the hip joint, the femoral head is so badly damaged and can lead to pseudoarthrosis.
  • Septic arthritis- It is seen when the metaphysics is intraarticular, in very young infants as the growth plate is penetrable, and from metastatic infection
  • Pathological fracture- It is an uncommon complication, but can occur if there is a treatment delay and a weakened bone due to erosion or overzealous debridement.
  • Chronic osteomyelitis

questions.text:
Match the following tests with the ligament injuries they are used to examine.

                 

1)Apley test  a)Medial collateral ligament
2)Lachman test b)Posterior cruciate ligament
3)McMurray test  c)Anterior cruciate ligament
4)Valgus stress test  d)Menisci
questions.solution:
The correctly matched options are as follows:

1)Apley test  d)Menisci
2)Lachman test c)Anterior cruciate ligament
3)McMurray test  d)Menisci
4)Valgus stress test  a)Medial collateral ligament

It is to be noted here that both Apley grinding test and McMurray test are done to test meniscal injuries.

Apley test: This test is performed with a prone patient, the knee is flexed to 90  degrees and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. Reproduction of symptoms indicates a torn meniscus. The distraction test involves repeated rotation while the leg is pulled upwards by the examiner, holding the thigh down. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.

The Lachman test is also done to detect injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament. Here the leg is in slight external rotation and the knee is flexed 20 degrees. One hand is placed to stabilize the femur and another hand applies the anterior force to the proximal tibia to look for any abnormal movement.

McMurray test: Done to detect menisci injuries. The patient's knee is completely flexed while he lies supine. One hand is used to stabilize and palpate the knee joint and the leg is internally and externally rotated with the other hand. The leg is then slowly extended. Meniscal injury presents as a palpable or audible click.

The valgus stress test is performed with the knee extended by placing one hand along the lateral thigh and pressing inward while the other hand is placed on the medial aspect of the ankle and pushed outward as shown in the image below. It is positive in medial collateral ligament injury.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male patient suffered from fracture of his right lower limb a few months back following which he developed a deformity while walking. On examination, it was found that his right leg became shorter than his left following fracture healing. The physician advised the following limb lengthening procedure as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is/are correct about this procedure?
  1. It can be used for arthrodesis
  2. K wire can be used in this apparatus
  3. The principle of this procedure is bone induction
  4. Compression or distraction is done at a rate of 1mm per day
  5. It is contraindicated in osteomyelitis of the same limb
questions.solution:
Statements 1,2,4 are correct.

The above radiograph depicts the lengthening of the limb with Ilizarov apparatus. 

Distraction osteogenesis also known as distraction histogenesis is the principle of Ilizarov technique.

Ilizarov's technique:

Distraction osteogenesis is the mechanical induction of new bone that occurs between bony surfaces that are gradually pulled apart. Ilizarov described this as “the tension stress effect.”

The most important application of the tension-stress principle is known as callus distraction (or callotaxis). A careful fracture of the bone is performed, followed by a short wait. The young callus formed is gradually distracted using a circular or unilateral external fixator. 

Osteogenesis requires a dynamic state by either a controlled distraction or a controlled compression. This dynamic force causes dormant mesenchymal cells at the non-union site to differentiate into functioning osteoblasts. This results in bone synthesis and fracture healing. The fixation system is called a ring fixator.  Distraction or compression can be applied by twisting nuts on the fixation system at the fracture or corticotomy site.  Distraction or compression is carried out at the rate of 1 mm per day. This is done in four sittings— ¼ mm, four times a day. This is used in limb lengthening or filling of large segmental defects in the bone.

Uses:

  • Limb lengthening
  • Non-union
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis - as it offers the possibility of liberal excision of bone
  • Arthrodesis - crushing articular surfaces can stimulate union between opposing bones

Kirschner wire or K-wire is used in Ilizarov ring fixator.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of progressive pain over her right wrist for the past 3 years. She was active in sports previously but worsening of pain forced her to stop all sports activities. On examination, there was a deformity in her right wrist and the pain was more on dorsiflexion. An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the X-ray are suggestive of Madelung deformity.

This deformity can be congenital or post-traumatic in which the distal radius growth plate fuses early, but the ulna continues to grow, therefore the lower ulna sticks out as a lump on the back of the wrist, and the distal radius curves ventrally. Distal ulna appears more prominent and longer than the distal radius, known as a positive ulnar variance. There is volar subluxation of the hand.

Vicker’s Ligament in Madelung Deformity

Vickers described an abnormal ligament that tethers the lunate to the distal radius proximal to the physis.

This ligament is believed to impede the growth of the ulnopalmar aspect of the distal radius and is commonly known as the ligament of Vickers.

Other options:

Option A: Gunstock deformity-Malunion following supracondylar fracture most commonly leads to cubitus varus which is known as gunstock deformity.

Option C: Haglund deformity: It is also known as pump bump or Mulholland deformity is seen in the ankle joint. It is a bony enlargement formed at the posterosuperior aspect of the calcaneum.

It is caused due to the chronic inflammation of the retrocalcaneal bursa. Recurrent pressure from the shoe may lead to chronic inflammation of the bursa and calcification at the site of insertion of the Achilles tendon.

Option D: Buttonhole deformity: Boutonnière deformity seen is rheumatoid arthritis is also known as buttonhole deformity. Here there is flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is being evaluated for chronic back pain. She also gives a history of using corticosteroids for bronchial asthma from her childhood. On examination kyphosis of the spine is present. MRI of the spine shows a 'codfish' vertebra. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the MRI showing codfish vertebrae are suggestive of osteoporosis and low body mass index (<18.5kg/m2) is a risk factor for osteoporosis. The MRI of the spine shows decreased bone density with a biconcave appearance of vertebrae known as codfish vertebrae. 

Osteoporosis is commonly seen in postmenopausal women because there is decreased estrogen after menopause. This results in increased osteoclastic activity and increased bone resorption.

Other important risk factors for osteoporosis are:

  • Alcohol
  • Smoking
  • Family history of hip fracture
  • Low body mass index- less than 18.5 kg/m2
  • Excessive usage of glucocorticoids

They present with fractures that occur without any trauma or as a result of low-impact trauma. The commonly associated fractures are fracture of the distal part of the radius (Colle's fracture), fractures of the hip, and fractures of the vertebrae. In severe cases, the fracture of vertebrae can cause kyphosis.

Diagnosis of osteoporosis is made by the T score. T score measures the patient's bone mineral density with that of a young adult. A score of ≤-2.5 is defined as osteoporosis.

Treatment- The mainstay of treatment is to reduce the risk of fractures. Following medications can be useful in the treatment

  • Bisphosphonates. They are the first line of medication. They reduce osteoclastic bone resorption and prevent bone loss. Eg. Zoledronate
  • Denosumab- This is an antibody to the RANK ligand. It prevents the activation of RANK which is required for the proliferation of osteoclasts. Therefore, it decreases bone resorption
  • Parathyroid hormone- Preotact and teriparatide are recombinant parathyroid hormone analogs. At low and intermittent doses, they can promote bone formation.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs)- They act on the estrogen receptors and prevent bone resorption. Eg. raloxifene.
  • Strontium ranelate- It is thought to increase bone formation and reduce bone resorption.
  • Cathepsin K inhibitor- Odnacatib is a cathepsin K inhibitor that inhibits the activity of collagenases.
  • Sclerostin inhibitor- Sclerostin inhibits the activity of osteoblasts. Romosozumab is a humanized antisclerostin monoclonal antibody that increases bone formation.

If the fractures are already present, they need operative treatment.

questions.text: A 56-year-old-male patient with uncontrolled diabetes presents to the casualty with gangrene involving his left foot. On examination, there is extensive tissue damage with bone involvement. As the foot cannot be salvaged, the surgeon plans to amputate his left foot. Which of the following statements is true regarding amputations that can be used in this condition?

choices.text: Chopart’s amputation is preferred if there is calcaneal involvement
Syme's amputation is technically more difficult than Boyd amputation
Lisfranc amputation is at the level of transverse tarsal joints
Sarmiento amputation involves excision of medial and lateral malleoli

questions.solution:
Sarmiento amputation involves excision of medial and lateral malleoli along with excision of the distal tibia and fibula 1.3cm proximal to the ankle joint.

Other options:

Option A: Chopart's amputation is done at the level of transverse tarsal joints and it can be done only if calcaneum and talus are free of infection.

Option B: Boyd's amputation is more difficult than Syme's amputation as it involves arthrodesis.

Option C: Lisfranc amputation is done at the level of tarsometatarsal joints.

questions.text: A 40 -year-old patient came with deformities, swellings, and pain in multiple areas of the limbs, her X-rays of the hands are given below. On examination, her skin doesn't have any hemangiomas. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows multiple tumors affecting the bones of the hand with soft tissue swellings and calcification which is suggestive of multiple enchondromatosis. Multiple enchondromas when present without hemangiomas is called Ollier disease. 

Enchondromas are benign bone tumors of hyaline cartilage which arise from the medullary canal.

Ollier disease is a rare condition in which many cartilaginous tumors appear in the large and small tubular bones and in the flat bones. It is caused by the failure of normal endochondral ossification.

Note: Enchondromatosis with hemangioma of the overlying soft tissue constitutes Maffucci’s syndrome.

questions.text: All of the following are indications of surgery in a patient of Potts' spine except?

choices.text: Progressive cauda equina syndrome/conus medullaris syndrome

questions.solution:
A cold abscess without neurological complications is not an indication for surgery in Pott’s spine/TB spine.

Indications of surgery in TB spine are:

  • Progressive neurologic deficit such as progressive cauda equina syndrome/conus medullaris syndrome (Option D)
  • Progressive increase in spinal deformity
  • Resistance to anti-tubercular therapy (Option C)
  • Recurrence of disease
  • Cord compression
  • Severe pain due to abscess or spinal instability
  • Progressive impairment of pulmonary function
  • Uncertain diagnosis (Option B): Inability to obtain a microbiological diagnosis through microscopy, culture, or PCR techniques may occur. In cases where there is no accessible source for sampling (such as discharging sinus or superficial abscess) or insufficient specimen obtained from image-guided percutaneous biopsy, an open surgical biopsy is the only option to obtain a specific culture and sensitivity report.

Antero-lateral decompression is the surgery of choice for Pott’s paraplegia as it helps in the removal of both solid and liquid debris.

questions.text: In case of a meniscal tear repair, which of the following zones heals best?
questions.solution:
The red zone heals best in case of a meniscal tear due to its rich blood supply.

The menisci are divided into three zones depending on the perfusion of blood. The menisci are supplied by perimeniscal blood vessels from superior and inferior branches of medial and lateral genicular vessels.

Following birth, the menisci become increasingly avascular. By adulthood, only the peripheral 10% to 25% of the tissue is perfused. This gives rise to 3 distinct regions of the menisci:

  • The peripheral relatively vascularised region called the red-red zone (Zone 1)
  • A zone of transition between the 2 zones, which is called the red-white zone (Zone 2)
  • The completely avascular inner zone known as the white-white zone (Zone 3)

There is a direct relationship between the vascularization and capacity of the tissue to heal, predisposing the white-white zone to permanent post-traumatic and degenerative lesions.

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient presents to you with complaints of pain and inability to do pinching activities, after suffering a fall on an outstretched hand while practicing skiing for the winter sports events. Which of the following structure is usually injured in the given scenario? (DIP- distal interphalangeal joints)

choices.text: Injury to extensor tendon at DIP
Injury to flexor tendon at DIP

questions.solution:
Clinical history of a Skier falling on an outstretched hand, after which pinching activities are affected, is suggestive of Gamekeeper’s thumb/Skier's thumb. It involves injury to Ulnar collateral ligament.

A gamekeeper thumb, also known as skier’s thumb is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The UCL may get ruptured or avulsed from its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx.

Injury is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with radial and palmar abduction. Patients present with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis around the first metacarpophalangeal joint. Diagnosis can be made on plain radiographs and/or anteroposterior stress radiographs.

In a partial rupture:

  • Only the ligament is torn and the thumb is unstable only in flexion 
  • The volar plate is intact, keeping the thumb stable in extension

In a complete rupture:

  • Both the ligament and the volar plate are torn 
  • The thumb is unstable in all positions

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A patient who had a left supracondylar fracture of the humerus a few years back now presents with a progressed deformity as shown in the image given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the deformity?

choices.text: Most commonly involved tendons are flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus
The deformity exaggerates on flexing the wrist
Most commonly involved nerve is median nerve
Max Page's operation is done for moderate deformities

questions.solution:
The given deformity is a claw hand seen as a result of Volkmann's ischemic contracture. The deformity exaggerates on extending the wrist(not on flexing).

Ischemic contracture of muscles affected by arterial injury or compartment syndrome is known as Volkmann’s ischaemic contracture (VIC). VIC in the forearm is most commonly seen following supracondylar humeral fractures. The most common nerve involved in VIC is the median nerve. The most common tendons involved are Flexor Digitorum Profundus and Flexor Pollicis Longus.

The classical clinical picture of established Volkmann contracture includes elbow flexion, forearm pronation, wrist flexion, thumb adduction, metacarpophalangeal joint extension, and finger flexion. 

Volkmann's sign: The deformity disappears on flexion and appears on the extension of the wrist.

Treatment of VIC

  • Mild deformities - passive stretching of the contracted muscles with a turn-buckle splint (Volkmann’s splint)
  • Moderate deformities - soft tissue sliding procedures (Max Page operation)
  • Severe deformities - early excision of all necrotic muscles, combined with complete median and ulnar neurolysis. This is followed by a secondary procedure of tendon transfers to restore function. If motor activity is not present in these tendons, a free innervated Gracilis muscle transfer may be considered.

questions.text: A counterforce brace is used in?
questions.solution:
A counterforce brace is used in tennis elbow.

Tennis elbow, also known as lateral epicondylitis, is a condition involving the lateral epicondyle caused by repetitive contraction of the extensor muscles during activities that require forceful wrist extension and supination, such as playing tennis or using a screwdriver.

A counterforce brace is a treatment option for tennis elbow (shown in the image below). It works by applying compression to the extensor muscles, specifically the extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) region, which helps release the forces exerted on the lateral epicondyle. This compression prevents the transmission of tension up to the lateral epicondyle, providing relief and promoting healing in the affected area.

Management options in tennis elbow:

  • Conservative management: Rest and physiotherapy
  • Medical intervention: Injection of local anesthetic and steroids
  • Surgical methods: Percutaneous release of epicondylar muscles
  • Other management methods: Extracorporeal shock wave therapy, arthroscopic release, autologous blood injections, counterforce bracing, rehabilitative exercises, and ultrasound-guided percutaneous needle therapy.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: A patient who sustained a talar fracture before 6 weeks now came for follow-up. His  X-Ray shows the presence of Hawkin's Sign.  What does this indicate?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of talus is likely
Avascular necrosis of calcaneum is unlikely
Avascular necrosis of talus is unlikely
Avascular necrosis of calcaneum is likely

questions.solution:
A patient who has sustained a talar fracture before 6 weeks and now showing Hawkin's sign in an X-ray of talus indicates avascular necrosis of talus is unlikely to develop.

Avascular necrosis/osteonecrosis is a complication that occurs following the fracture of the neck of the talus. It is seen in the body of the talus.

The earliest radiograph finding is the increased density of the avascular segment whereas the rest of the talus has become porotic due to disuse. Hawkin's sign indicates that the dome of the talus has become osteoporotic, implying it has a blood supply. This is looked at 6-8 weeks after the injury. 

If there is a dense segment of the talus bone after a few weeks of the talus fracture, it means there is an avascular segment. This is the earliest X-ray sign of avascular necrosis of the body of the talus. 

Weight-bearing should be delayed. Arthrodesis of the ankle is recommended when there is flattening or fragmentation of the talus. It can also be done when the pain and disability are marked. 

The X-ray below shows the presence of subchondral lucency or Hawkin's sign.

questions.text: Soon after birth, an infant is noted to have paralysis of the left hand with ipsilateral ptosis and miosis. The suspected diagnosis can also be associated with the following conditions except

questions.text: A 13-year old boy with 70 kg weight and hypothyroidism presents with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the hip. There is tenderness in Scarpa's triangle. On flexing the hip, the limb is externally rotated. Which of the following signs will be positive?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis in the above case is slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SCFE). Trethowan's sign is seen in SCFE.

Points in favor of SCFE:

  • 13-year old child: As SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, commonly during 11-20 years, due to the weakening of upper femoral physis. Most common age of presentation of Perthe's disease is 4-8 years.
  • Obesity and hypothyroidism: Obesity, hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, hyperparathyroidism, growth hormone excess, Turner's syndrome, Klinefelter's syndrome, and chronic renal failure are all important associations of SCFE.
  • Limitation of abduction and internal rotation
  • Tenderness in scarpa's triangle

Trethowan's sign is seen in SCFE. When Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis, it is known as Trethowan’s sign.

Klein's line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck that normally is intersected by the epiphysis.

 

Other options:

Siffert Katz sign: In Blount's disease, the knee is stable in full extension, but the medial femoral condyle may sublux posteromedially (into the depressed medial tibial plateau) at 10-20 degrees of flexion. This is called Siffert-katz sign.

The increased gap between the scaphoid and the lunate has been named the Terry Thomas sign after the gap-toothed smile. A scapholunate gap of >3 mm is suggestive of instability, with a gap >5 mm diagnostic of SLD if there is a positive cortical ring sign.

Spur sign: Seen in transverse fracture of acetabulum.

questions.text: An infant with a large head and normal length was brought with failure to thrive. On examination hepatosplenomegaly and frontal bossing were noted. Blood tests show pancytopenia and X-ray imaging is done which is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A presentation of failure to thrive in an infant with a large head, normal length, pancytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and the X-ray image showing dense bones is suggestive of osteopetrosis. 

Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease/Albers–Schönberg disease:

It is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to mutation of CLCN7 (in osteoclasts).

Clinical features: Macrocephaly (due to hydrocephalus), developmental delay, pancytopenia (reduced bone marrow cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Blood investigation: Low serum calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D levels.

Radiological features: Plain radiographs are usually diagnostic. Diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies can be seen. The skull base shows uniform radiodensity

Treatment: Symptomatic treatment and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can be done.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the deformity shown?

choices.text: Little finger is the most commonly involved
It is more common in males
Fasciectomy with skin grafting is done in cases with recurrence
May be associated with Ledderhose and Peyronie’s disease

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Dupuytren’s contracture. The ring finger is most commonly involved.

Dupuytren's contracture is due to the proliferation of previously normal subcutaneous palmar and digital tissues manifesting as nodules and cords that may affect hand function by causing finer and thumb joint flexion contractures.

The contracture begins with increased fibroblast proliferation followed by type III collagen deposition resulting in uncontrolled palmar fascia growth ultimately causing flexion contractures.

The distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) are not involved. The metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are involved. The order of involvement of fingers - ring finger > little finger > middle finger > index finger > thumb.

It is more common in males and the incidence is higher in patients with cirrhosis of the liver, diabetes, smoking, and AIDS. It is also associated with vibration exposure to the wrist and hand. The contractures are usually limited to the medial 3 fingers.

Dupuytren contractures may be associated with similar ectopic lesions in the medial plantar fascia of one or both feet (Ledderhose disease), as plastic penile induration (Peyronie disease), and knuckle pads (Garrod nodules) may present over the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints dorsally.

Treatment:

  • Observation- observation at every three months interval for mild deformities.
  • Radiotherapy- is given only during the early fibroblastic phase.
  • Surgery- is the best-known treatment and is delayed until actual contractures develop. The various procedures performed are:
    • Subcutaneous fasciotomy- preferred in elderly arthritic patients
    • Partial selective fasciotomy- indicated only when the ulnar two fingers are involved
    • Complete fasciectomy- rarely done
    • Fasciectomy with skin grafting- done in young people with epilepsy, alcoholism, and in cases of recurrence after excision
    • Amputation- considered if flexion contractures of PIP joint are very severe
    • Resection and arthrodesis- done for severe contractures of the PIP joint. It is better than amputation as it prevents amputation neuroma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with back pain radiating to the leg after lifting a heavy suitcase. There is sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the ​leg, dorsum of the foot, and great toe. The medial hamstring reflex is diminished. The knee and ankle jerks are normal. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this case scenario is L4-L5 disc prolapse.

The points given in the question in favor of this diagnosis are back pain radiating to the leg, sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the ​leg, dorsum of the foot, great toe, diminished medial hamstring reflex, and normal ankle jerk. 

The prolapsed intervertebral disc (PIVD) usually presents in adults between 20 to 40 years. The most common symptom is low back pain. It can be associated with or without pain radiating down the back of the leg (sciatica). 

Neurological features of L4-L5 PIVD are: 

  • Weakness of extensor hallucis longus and dorsiflexor muscles of the foot
  • Sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of knee and leg, dorsum of the foot, and the great toe. One or more adjacent toes may also be involved (i.e., 1st web space) but never the little toe
  • Diminished medial hamstring reflex
  • Knee jerk and ankle jerk are normal.

Tests for diagnosis:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT): 

This test is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area. The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in a neutral position. Affected leg passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. SLRT test negative if the leg can be raised 80–90 degrees without pain. SLRT test positive if pain elicited between 30-60 or 70 degrees from horizontal. Lasègue's test is a modified SLRT where the knee is bent to 90 degrees. 

2. Crossed straight-leg test: 

SLRT on the unaffected side. Pain felt on the affected side and is termed as contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is often highly specific for a large central prolapse. 

3. Bowstring sign or popliteal compression test: 

This test is more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. It is performed by eliciting SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Now without reducing the amount of lift, the knee is bent to relax the sciatic nerve. The pain in the buttocks is immediately relieved. Following this, the popliteal fossa is pressed to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. Tightening of the nerve like a bowstring re-induces the pain. 

MRI is the investigation of choice.

Treatment:

  • Bed rest, heat, ice, NSAIDs, muscle relaxants and/or spinal traction are commonly advised
  • Operative removal of the prolapsed disc: 
    • Absolute indication - cauda equina compression syndrome 
    • Relative indications - neurological deterioration, persistent pain and/or failed conservative treatment

questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis arrived from the above-given clinical scenario is Brodie’s abscess.

Brodie abscess is a localized form of subacute osteomyelitis that occurs most often in the long bones of the lower extremities of young adults. It usually presents with intermittent pain that lasts long and local tenderness over the affected area.

The above X-ray shows the dense sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction in the upper end of the tibia.

All the given conditions may present a history of swelling and pain. However, the differentiating features of each of the given conditions are as follows:

Condition Age group Radiographic findings

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in her right hand. Her daily routine involves taking care of her 2 kids. Of late, she feels excruciating pain in certain movements of her hand. On examination, the Finkelstein test is positive. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved in this condition?

choices.text: Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the positive Finkelstein's test is suggestive of De Quervain's disease. The structures likely to be involved in this condition are extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It involves noninflammatory thickening of both the tendons and the tunnel or sheath through which they pass. This condition is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Key diagnostic factors:

  • History of joint overuse at home or at work
  • Pain and tenderness at the tip of radial styloid
  • Positive Finkelstein test

Finkelstein's test- the examiner grasps the thumb of the patient and abducts the hand towards the ulnar side. This causes severe pain over the tip of the styloid process. It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's disease (tenosynovitis)
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome i.e. tenosynovitis occurs due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis tendons and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons. 

The image below shows Finkelstein's test. 


Treatment of De Quervain's disease includes conservative management in the majority of the patients with steroid injection. Only a few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

questions.solution:
When elbow viewed from lateral position, the tip of the olecranon, the lateral epicondyle and radial head forms an equilateral triangle i.e anconeus triangle, the anatomical landmark for postrolateral portal for elbow arthroscopy.

Ward's triangle refers to a radiolucent area between principle compressive, secondary compressive and primary tensile trabeculae in the neck of femur. It is a sensitive indicator of osteoporosis, particularly in men, and should be used to identify patients at increased risk for osteoporosis-related fractures.

Bryant’s triangle is a right angled formed by:

  2. Tip of Greater trochanter
  3. Junction of perpendiculars from the 2 points above

The distance between the tip of greater trochanter and the junction of 2 perpendiculars measures supra-trochanteric shortening. It can occur in 

  1. Dislocation of hip
  2. Central fracture – dislocation of hip
  3. Destruction of head or acetabulum or both
  4. Fracture of the neck of femur

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presented with a flexion contracture of the hip. Which of the following tests is useful in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Thomas test is useful in diagnosing flexion contracture of the hip.

Flexion deformity is a common hip deformity, often caused by stronger flexor muscles overpowering the extensor muscles. When there is a spasm of the muscles, the stronger flexors pull the hip in flexion. Soft tissue contractures can convert this into a fixed flexion deformity, making locomotion impossible. 

The Thomas test is used to evaluate the degree of flexion deformity. The aim is to eliminate compensatory lumbar lordosis and reveal the obvious flexion deformity for measurement. 

During the test, the patient lies supine on a hard surface with legs straight. The patient may compensate for the flexion deformity by arching the lower back, creating excessive lumbar lordosis. The easy passage of the examiner's hand between the bed and the back of the patient is considered a positive test as normally this is not possible. 

By gradually flexing the unaffected hip, the pelvis tilts and eliminates lumbar lordosis, causing the affected hip to assume the flexed position. The angle between the affected thigh and the bed indicates the degree of flexion deformity.

 

Other options:

Option A: Allen's Test is mainly used to test the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand, which is usually done prior to radial artery cannulation.

Option B: Trendelenberg test is used to assess the weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius muscle.

Option D: Ober's test is used in physical examination to identify the tightness of the iliotibial band.

Melorheostosis: It is also known as Leri's Disease. It is a rare mesenchymal dysplasia manifesting as regions of sclerosis of cortices with a characteristic dripping wax appearance or flowing candle wax appearance. The presentation is usually monostotic and unilateral. Symptoms include pain, deformity, skin and circulation problems and contractures.

Osteopoikilosis is a benign autosomal dominant sclerosing bone dysplasia with multiple bone islands in a peri-articular distribution in tubular bones, pelvis and scapulae. They are typically bilateral and symmetrical.

Osteopathia striata, is a rare, benign dysplasia of bone with radiographically prominent vertical striations involving the epiphysis and metaphysis of tubular bones. It is typically asymptomatic, although there can be associated joint discomfort.
