questions.text: A female patient with a history of fall few months back presents with the deformity shown in the image. Probing into history reveals it was managed with traditional treatment. This deformity is likely to be due to ____________
questions.solution:
The given image shows the dinner-fork deformity seen in Colle's fracture which is an extra-articular fracture of the wrist.

Colle's fracture is a fracture of corticocancellous junction of the distal end of the radius. The dinner fork deformity is the prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. It is due to the dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment. It is treated by a Colles’ cast, which immobilizes the wrist in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.

Displacements that may be seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Dorsal tilt
  • Dorsal shift
  • Lateral tilt (Radial tilt)
  • Lateral shift (Radial shift)
  • Supination
  • Impaction of fragments

The given radiograph shows the dorsal tilt of the distal fragment leading to dinner fork deformity.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: Scoliosis screening in school children is done by?
questions.solution:
The forward bending test is used as a screening tool in scoliosis. 

Adam's forward bending test is the best clinical test for evaluating spinal curvature in scoliosis. 

Steps of Adam's test :

  • The patient is asked to bend forward at the waist until the spine is at the horizontal level
  • Knees must be maintained straight, with the feet together, the arms dependent, and the palms in opposition
  • The examiner observes the trunk from behind (to assess midthoracic and lumbar rotation) and from the front (to assess upper thoracic rotation)

It is used to differentiate between structural and non-structural curves in scoliosis. On bending forward, non-structural scoliosis disappears, while structural scoliosis persists. 


A straight leg raising test is used to find nerve compression in the lumbosacral area.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought by parents to the casualty. On examination varying degrees of ecchymosis is seen all over the body. X-ray shows a spiral fracture of the femur. Which of the following is not a part of the  Minimum Required Views in the  Standard Skeletal Survey required for this baby?

choices.text: AP views of the entire skeleton
Lateral views of wrists, ankles, knees
Dedicated views of hands and feet
Lateral views of skull, and spine

questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is battered baby syndrome.  Lateral views of wrists, ankles, knees is usually considered optional.

The presence of spiral fracture femur along with varying degrees of ecchymosis all over the body in a child indicates that the injuries have happened over a span of time, which suggests a diagnosis of the battered baby syndrome.

As per the Standard Skeletal Survey for Suspected Child Abuse, the minimum X-ray views required in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of the axial skeleton—skull, and spine.

Imaging Also Suggested

  • Oblique views of ribs
  • Oblique views of hands and feet

Optional Useful Images

  • Lateral views of the joints—wrists, ankles, knees
  • Orthogonal views of any fractures found

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was brought with complaints of bilateral knee pain. On examination, he had pinpoint ecchymoses around the hair follicles. His X-ray appears as given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the X-ray image showing Pelkan spurs, Trummerfeld zone, Frenkel's line, and Wimberger's ring sign are suggestive of scurvy.

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline. Hence, deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in generalized bleeding tendencies.

Clinical features:

Early manifestations include irritability, loss of appetite, musculoskeletal pain, and tenderness in the legs. Later on, the child can have swelling of the knees, ankles, and pseudo paralysis. Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and characteristic perifollicular hemorrhages.

Other manifestations are poor wound and fracture healing, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, arthralgia, and muscle weakness. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated also known as the scorbutic rosary.

Radiographic features of scurvy include:

  • Wimberger's ring sign - sharp margination of the epiphysis by a sclerotic rim
  • White line of Frankel - calcified cartilage at metaphyses
  • Trumerfeld zone - a lucent zone beneath the Frankel's line due to lack of mineralisation of osteoid
  • Pelkan spurs - due to fractures at the cortical margin
  • Periosteal elevation - due to subperiosteal haemorrhages

 

Other options:

Option A: Rickets occurs due to vitamin D deficiency in children. The patients present with skeletal changes like bowing of legs and bone pain. Radiological features show cupping at metaphysis, fraying, and widening of the growth plate.

Option B: Caffey’s disease is infantile cortical hyperostosis. It usually presents at 6 months of age with painful soft tissue swelling and bone thickening. The mandible is the most common bone involved.

Option D: Osteogenesis imperfecta presents with the hallmark features of osteoporosis with increased fragility of bones along with blue sclera, dental fragility as well as hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary
